description: Eating etiquette in Malaysia reflects religious values, cultural diversity, and shared dining practices across different ethnic groups.

guidelines.text: Food is commonly cut into bite-sized pieces, so knives are rarely used during meals.
People often eat with their hands. Restaurants may provide a water pitcher for washing hands instead of utensils.
Always wash your hands before eating or serving food.
The right hand should be used to bring food to the mouth and to offer food to others.
When dining at a restaurant, the host usually orders all the dishes.
Leaving a small amount of food on your plate indicates that the meal was satisfying. Emptying the plate may suggest that you want more.
It is considered poor etiquette to walk while eating.
Malay meals are commonly eaten with the hands or with a spoon and fork. Pork is generally avoided.
Malaysian Indian meals are commonly eaten with a spoon or with the hands. Beef is typically avoided.
Malaysian Chinese meals often use spoons, forks, or chopsticks. Chopsticks should not be placed vertically in a rice bowl as this is associated with mourning.
